newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: BAe Australian unit wins Canadian contract.
newsitem.headline: BAe Australian unit wins Canadian contract.

text.p: British Aerospace Plc's Australian subsidiary will supply Canada with equipment for its Nulka naval missile decoy system, the company said on Monday.

"Under a contract signed June 5, British Aerospace Australia will supply Nulka Fire Control Systems and launchers to the Canadian navy, for its Iroquois Class destroyers," British Aerospace Australia said in a statement.
The Australian Nulka system fires hovering rockets that lure anti-ship missiles away from their target ship.
The company said it expected to sign a multi-million dollar contract to provide Nulka decoy rounds to Canada, Australia and the United States soon.
The Nulka programme originated in Australia and was developed by British Aerospace Australia in a joint venture for the Australian and United States navies.
The fire control systems feature touch screen panels produced by Computer Devices Canada. The company said the lightweight launchers each held four Nulka decoys.
The Royal Australian Navy purchased the control systems and launchers under a A$58 million contract last August to mount on its FFG-7 and ANZAC class ships.
